snippet: When a New York software company, LaRonde Technical Consulting, was sued recently in California, the company argued that the case was not within the jurisdiction of California's courts. It was an age-old legal claim, with a high-technology twist: ...
lead_paragraph: When a New York software company, LaRonde Technical Consulting, was sued recently in California, the company argued that the case was not within the jurisdiction of California's courts. It was an age-old legal claim, with a high-technology twist: The company said it could not be sued in the state because its dealings with the California plaintiff had been largely through electronic mail. In a strongly worded opinion issued earlier this month, a California appellate court disagreed. It said state courts could hold jurisdiction over parties whose transactions in California were largely done via E-mail and the telephone.
abstract: California appellate court recently found that state courts could hold jurisdiction over parties whose transactions in California were largely done via E-mail and telephone; case touches on larger issue of jurisdiction and cyberspace, where many unresolved questions are not as clear-cut as those surrounding E-mail; among these are questions about how courts will view other parts of Internet, including sites on World Wide Web and File Transfer Protocol and Telnet sites; ultimately, answers will dictate not just where courts have jurisdiction, but what governments have right to tax and regulate Internet businesses (M)

headline.main: Courts Beginning to Make Order on Frontiers of Cyberspace
